THE PREVIEW
The Preview, held in the Valley College auditorium two nights prior to the
first broadcast, was arranged with recruiting of group organizers clearly in mind*
Arrangements were handled largely by a volunteer committee of the Community Educa¬
tion Project, consisting chiefly of people who had participated in previous discus¬
sion groups arranged by the Project.
The agenda of the Preview was designed to produce the maximum audience parti¬
cipation. The total program was explained, Dr, C-oldschmidt described the develop¬
ment of the radio series, and exoerpts from several of the programs were played.
Eight people, drawn from participants in previous discussion programs, staged
a demonstration of a home discussion group in action* It was announced that an album
containing all of the Ways of Mankind recordings would be awarded at the end of the
series to the first ten groups to (l) organize, (2) register with the Community
Education Office,(3) continue to exist throughout the series, and (4) submit weekly
evaluations of the programs. Finally,the entire audience was divided into small
unanswered
buzz groups of six or seven people to formuhte/questions about forming home discus¬
sion groups. Reporters from these buzz groups came to the stage and presented their
questions to a panel of "experts" (persons with considerable previous experience in
discussion groups.)
At the conclusion of the meeting, special manuals giving detaibd instructions
on how to organize Ways of Mankind listen<-and-talk gmups were distributed to all in¬
terested persons* On the way out of the auditorium those intending to organize
groups were invited to register their groups and thus become eligible for the prizes.

pation was almost one hundred per cent. Subsequent analysis showed that vdth the
